title: No High Contrast selection highlight for TextEditorDecorations when on High Contrast theme
body:
Version: 1.35.1 (user setup)
Commit: c7d83e57cd18f18026a8162d042843bda1bcf21f
Date: 2019-06-12T14:30:02.622Z
Electron: 3.1.8
Chrome: 66.0.3359.181
Node.js: 10.2.0
V8: 6.6.346.32
OS: Windows_NT x64 10.0.18362

This may be a feature request, however it has to do with a potential deficiency wrt accessibility, so opening as a bug.

Using the default High Contrast theme, selecting text will effectively replace the foreground color of the text, to ensure the selection is still 'high contrast'.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49173979/59954174-3fbde600-9438-11e9-8abf-0d00ce10e981.png)

However, text decorations do not get similar treatment:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49173979/59954532-fe2e3a80-9439-11e9-920d-1a4cdfccd328.png)


I don't see a way to apply a foreground selection color on a DecorationRenderOptions, or a way to apply raw CSS to try to address the issue myself.  (Please let me know if there is a way I am overlooking).  This would suggest that there is an issue with contrast of selection highlight for any/all TextEditorDecorations.

title: Provide Code-Levels
body:
...to solving some Cross-Cutting Concerns (ccc) in development.

The idea to solve the problem of ccc is to create mutliplie level 
of code (code-lines) for one class/file at design time. 
These level are mixed togheter by the ide at runtime or can also viewed 
by designtime.

The system is more syntaxtic sugar of an ide feature as it is a pattern or archtecture, but
it is focused to make the readability of code better without disadvantages of performance lossing or hardreading code like in the AOP. 

This is a typcial behavior in drawing programs (for example, paint.net, Inkscape, â€¦), to focus on one part of a picture. So why not use this for coding?

The following is a much simplified example:




![CodeLevel](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9537955/59929492-37b67400-9441-11e9-8668-199d1f595bc4.gif)

title: Support the git-client protocol address

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Github website offers a nice button on the clone menu - "Open in Visual Studio" which let you clone+open the repo directly on Visual Studio, it use `git-client` protocol, e.g.:

[git-client://clone?repo=https%3A%2F%2Fgithub.com%2Fmicrosoft%2Fvscode](git-client://clone?repo=https%3A%2F%2Fgithub.com%2Fmicrosoft%2Fvscode)
Would open Visual Studio if the Github extension is installed.

It would be nice to have vscode supporting this protocol, from briefly looking on [extensions/git/src/protocolHandler.ts](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/master/extensions/git/src/protocolHandler.ts) it seems like it already support it and just need to register itself upon installation (?)

Together with 	`git.defaultCloneDirectory` it would be super easy (=one click) to use vscode for browsing through code from Github.
![Annotation 2019-06-21 163124](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17422884/59929939-202bbb00-9442-11e9-813e-037df9378320.png)

title: Typescript language server plugin should use a different workspace config key
code --wait --diff doesn't exit after closing diff if the file is also opened in a non-diff view
body:
Issue Type: Bug I have vscode configured as my difftool with this my git config: ``` [diff] tool = vscode [difftool] prompt = false [difftool "vscode"] cmd = code --wait --diff $LOCAL $REMOTE ``` This case works correctly: 1. Start with no open files, and with an unstaged commit to a local file (e.g. foo.txt) 2. In the integrated terminal, run `git diftool foo.txt` 3. The diff shows up as a new tab 4. Close the tab 5. `git difftool foo.txt` exits This case does not work correctly: 1. Start with foo.txt open, and with an unstaged commit to foo.txt 2. In the integrated terminal, run `git diftool foo.txt` 3. The diff shows up as a new tab 4. Close the tab that shows the diff 5. `git difftool foo.txt` does not exit 6. Close the other tab that has foo.txt 7. Now `git difftool foo.txt` exits If it's relevant, I'm using the Remote SSH extension. title: vscode-node-debug assumes debug port open when --inspect-port is used for "attach to process"
body:
[https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-node-debug says to file issues in this repo]

If you run a node process with `node --inspect-port=1234 sleep-forever.js`, the VSCode `${command:PickProcess}` command picker suggests to connect to the process using port 1234.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/60228/59865012-e0c77680-933c-11e9-956f-5047acf28821.png)

However, because `--inspect` wasn't specified, the port isn't opened until a `kill -USR1 <pid>` is issued, so the picker doesn't work. A workaround is to kill the process.

I suspect the issue is at https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-node-debug/blob/56dc3892885b3122385b785322b00a92d33fdded/src/node/extension/protocolDetection.ts#L233 where the regexp looking for `--inspect` is finding `--inspect-port` and assuming debugging is already "open."

In my environment, I'm trying to setup distinct, different ports for my different node processes so that multiple can be debugged simultaneously, so I'm using `--inspect-port` to facilitate that, but I don't wish to have the debugging enabled by default. (I'm starting the processes outside of VSCode at the moment.)

Note that if the node process updates `process.title` this picker fails in other interesting ways, but that's much more of an edge case.

This issue is similar to https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/46664 but I think a slightly different workflow.

- VSCode Version: 1.35.1 
- OS Version: Mac OS 10.14.5 

Steps to Reproduce:

0. Install vscode-node-debug
1. Start a node process with `--inspect-port`
2. Create a debug configuration following "Attach to Process"
3. Try to attach; observe that it tries to connect using the port rather than SIGUSR1.

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: n/a

title: Setting to render active line number
body: Currently, we have `editor.renderLineHighlight` which is useful if you want to show or hide the current line highlight. But there's no setting for the active line number, you need manually check the theme's `editorLineNumber.foreground` and use it in `workbench.colorCustomizations`. The new setting could be `editor.renderActiveLineNumber` or something like that.

title: Allow QuickPicks to show right-aligned text like "recently opened" in the command palette
body: Extensions can't currently render text like "recently opened" here, but it'd be nice if we could. This was raised in https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/75236 and taken as a feature request, but the OP closed it, so here's a new request (cc @chrmarti) :-)

title: Add option to restore commit template on every git.refresh

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
(fixes #75651)

~~@joaomoreno unfortunately, I couldn't figure out how to set up the local development environment for building and testing the change.~~
~~Could you please review and test it? Or should I first solve my installation problems?~~

~~Thanks!~~

**Edit:**
I tested my changes and modified it a bit so that it works now as I would expect it:

* There is a new setting `git.restoreCommitTemplateOnRefresh`, which defaults to `true`.
* If this setting is set, the manually triggered command `git.refresh` also triggers the restoring of the template.
* If also `git.autorefresh` is set, the template gets restored automatically.

I would appreciate if you could now review my changes. :)

title: Installing from a VSIX fails if it's version is older than the installed version and another installed extension depends on it

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
To repro:

- Install the Flutter extension (which depends on Dart and will install it)
- Try to install Dart from an older-versioned VSIX (eg. https://github.com/Dart-Code/Dart-Code/releases/tag/v3.1.0-beta.3)

This fails because installing Dart tries to uninstall the old version, however this fails because Flutter depends on it.

I raised this before in https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/48489 but then couldn't repro it, however I'm seeing it all the time now (and have been for some time - I forgot the original issue had been closed).

title: Snap "classic" confinement makes Snapcraft's snapshot feature useless
body:
Currently VSCode Snap is created with Snap's [classic confinement](https://docs.snapcraft.io/snap-confinement), which means that Snapcraft doesn't handle application or user state, making the [snapshot feature](https://docs.snapcraft.io/snapshots) useless.

When creating a Snap with _strict confinement (default)_, Snapcraft sandboxes the application and runs in an isolated secure environment, and overrides various environment variables. With classic confinement, [this is not the case](https://github.com/snapcore/snapd/wiki/Environment-Variables#home).

> **Classic**
> Allows access to your systemâ€™s resources in much the same way traditional packages do. To safeguard against abuse, publishing a classic snap requires manual approval, and installation requires the --classic command line argument.

All application/user data created with Snap applications using _strict confinement_ can be manipulated with the Snapcraft snapshot feature. Why isn't Code under strict confinement?

See examples for Code _(classic)_ and ngrok _(strict)_ below.

VSCode (`code`) has the following CLI arguments: `--user-data-dir` and `--extensions-dir` so this can be set/overridden, but the user of the Snap cannot set these. Unless doing something like this:

```bash
$ snap run --shell code
$ code
$ code --user-data-dir=$SNAP_USER_DATA
```

I saw this issue which could possibly relate to this in some way: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/3884

<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: `1.35.1 c7d83e57cd18f18026a8162d042843bda1bcf21f x64`
- OS Version: `Linux Mint 19.1 (Ubuntu); 4.15.0-51-generic`

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install code snap (`snap install code --classic`)
2. Change user settings (`~/.config/Code/User/settings.json`)
3. Save state of snap (`snap save code`)
4. Change user settings again (`~/.config/Code/User/settings.json`)
5. Restore previous user settings (`snap restore 1`)

Previous version of `settings.json` is not restored.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

**Example: code (classic confinement)**

```bash
$ snap run --shell code
$ export | grep -E ' (USER|PATH|HOME|(SNAP|NODE)_.+)=".+"$'

declare -x HOME="/home/gaui"
declare -x PATH="/home/gaui/.nvm/versions/node/v11.10.1/bin:/usr/local/sbin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/bin:/sbin:/bin:/usr/games:/usr/local/games:/snap/bin:/home/gaui/go/bin:/home/gaui/go/bin"
declare -x SNAP_ARCH="amd64"
declare -x SNAP_COMMON="/var/snap/code/common"
declare -x SNAP_CONTEXT="Ljl4wyHRmyxMyJXHw1PDFmxTSY3cVHPYsKHnxymY6C8L"
declare -x SNAP_COOKIE="Ljl4wyHRmyxMyJXHw1PDFmxTSY3cVHPYsKHnxymY6C8L"
declare -x SNAP_DATA="/var/snap/code/9"
declare -x SNAP_INSTANCE_NAME="code"
declare -x SNAP_LIBRARY_PATH="/var/lib/snapd/lib/gl:/var/lib/snapd/lib/gl32:/var/lib/snapd/void"
declare -x SNAP_NAME="code"
declare -x SNAP_REVISION="9"
declare -x SNAP_USER_COMMON="/home/gaui/snap/code/common"
declare -x SNAP_USER_DATA="/home/gaui/snap/code/9"
declare -x SNAP_VERSION="c7d83e57"
declare -x USER="gaui"
```

**Example: ngrok (strict confinement)**

```bash
$ snap run --shell ngrok
$ export | grep -E ' (USER|PATH|HOME|(SNAP|NODE)_.+)=".+"$'

declare -x HOME="/home/gaui/snap/ngrok/13"
declare -x PATH="/usr/local/sbin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/bin:/sbin:/bin:/usr/games:/usr/local/games"
declare -x SNAP_ARCH="amd64"
declare -x SNAP_COMMON="/var/snap/ngrok/common"
declare -x SNAP_CONTEXT="DPGlHy5JTBsW1Vdc84k6mjJJtX4sprMDB0Gy0vCclJKH"
declare -x SNAP_COOKIE="DPGlHy5JTBsW1Vdc84k6mjJJtX4sprMDB0Gy0vCclJKH"
declare -x SNAP_DATA="/var/snap/ngrok/13"
declare -x SNAP_INSTANCE_NAME="ngrok"
declare -x SNAP_LIBRARY_PATH="/var/lib/snapd/lib/gl:/var/lib/snapd/lib/gl32:/var/lib/snapd/void"
declare -x SNAP_NAME="ngrok"
declare -x SNAP_REVISION="13"
declare -x SNAP_USER_COMMON="/home/gaui/snap/ngrok/common"
declare -x SNAP_USER_DATA="/home/gaui/snap/ngrok/13"
declare -x SNAP_VERSION="2.3.27"
declare -x USER="gaui"
```

title: Smart "editor.find.autoFindInSelection" ?
body: Issue Type: Feature Request Right now, the editor.find.autoFindInSelection and editor.find.seedSearchStringFromSelection don't work well together: a basic use case is to select a word, then Ctrl-F to find the occurrences. The problem is that if editor.find.autoFindInSelection is true (which I really like), then the selection is the word itself. How about autoFindInSelection activate only if the selection is not the same as the selection used for seedSearchStringFromSelection ? VS Code version: Code 1.35.1 (c7d83e57cd18f18026a8162d042843bda1bcf21f, 2019-06-12T14:30:02.622Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.16299

title: Git commit template should be restored automatically (not only on commit)

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
## Background
In #39048, @joaomoreno says about the command `git.restoreCommitTemplate`:

> I don't think it's a command worth putting in the command palette. Seems to be very specific for users who actively modify .gitmessage, doesn't happen often.

This might be true, but there are definitely more actions (than just `commit`) where it would make sense to read the git commit template, because if you know what you can do with this, this is so damn useful. :)

## Problem:
Personally, I use the git commit template to follow our team's git commit message and branch naming conventions, which says that the commit message and the branch you are working on have to be prefixed with the id of the corresponding Jira issue.

So I created a git hook for writing the recently used commit message into the commit template on `post-commit` and also a hook on `post-checkout` to write the current branch name (title-cased) into the commit template when I create a new branch.
:heavy_check_mark: When I commit something, the git commit template updates and the last commit message stays in the scm message box.
:negative_squared_cross_mark: But in order to get the updated content from that template after a `git checkout`, I have to invoke `git.restoreCommitTemplate`.

Temporarily [I could fix this](https://gist.github.com/dmstern/d02ea41d4b0171ff2f4661daaa3e3f86) with a macro extension and mapped the `workbench.view.scm` keyboard shortcut to my new macro, which does both (`git.restoreCommitTemplate` and `workbench.view.scm`). But (a) this works only with this shortcut, not if I click on the scm icon in the activity bar and (b) I think this behavior should be possible without an extension.

## Possible solution:
Please invoke `git.restoreCommitTemplate` every time `workbench.view.scm` is invoked or on every [`git.refresh`](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/4e7545ba8a536237387848e2b8220d2b562ae041/extensions/git/src/commands.ts#L237)

title: Maximized editor group when debug step into file
body:
I made a gif and sketch to help understand, sorry for poor english.
i very love how `"workbench.editor.revealIfOpen": true` allow me easy manage my workflow.
The issue is when i use a  debugger, and nav with step breakpoint.
If the step need to go inside another file inside another group editor, it seem not work, the file does not maximize automatically, i need click manually on the files.

![idN3o](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24865815/59601029-de60e480-90d0-11e9-976e-2aa8e8b1d688.png)
As you can see, when i click on `nextStep`, the `breakPoint` change and highlighted into the next file in editor groupe from bottom, but the editor groupe not reveal `(maximized)` automatically. 
I need manually click on the slot to maximize the groups editor.

![maximize debug](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24865815/59600763-22071e80-90d0-11e9-966f-e99e128bc016.gif)

Do you have something i can add in `settings.json` to allow this ?
is missing setup ?
thanks a lot guys and keep nice work.

title: Extensions using the "type" command (for ex. Vim) have poor performance due to being single-threaded with other extensions
[json] formatter "heap out of memory" regression
body:
- VSCode Version: 1.35, 1.35.1
- OS Version: CentOS Linux release 7.6.1810 

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Format big JSON document (47MB). All extensions are disabled.
2. Formatter crashes with message "Extension host terminated unexpectedly."

Tested VSCode versions 1.23.1, 1.25.1, 1.26.1, 1.27.2, 1.28.2, 1.29.1, 1.30.2, 1.31.1, 1.32.3, 1.33.1, 1.34 and they worked well.
Version 1.35 introduced this "heap out of memory" crash.

Developer tools:
FATAL ERROR: CALL_AND_RETRY_LAST Allocation failed - JavaScript heap out of memory
 1: node::Abort() [/home/gv/opt/VSCode-linux-x64/libnode.so]
 2: 0x7f130212d867 [/home/gv/opt/VSCode-linux-x64/libnode.so]
 3: 0x7f1301b3104e [/home/gv/opt/VSCode-linux-x64/libnode.so]

title: Make proxy settings machine scoped
body: I believe the proxy settings we have are scoped to machine and so they should be tagged as Machine scoped.

title: Windows: Color of subpixel rendering changes when opening menu bar
body:
Version: 1.35.1 (user setup)
Commit: c7d83e57cd18f18026a8162d042843bda1bcf21f
Date: 2019-06-12T14:30:02.622Z
Electron: 3.1.8
Chrome: 66.0.3359.181
Node.js: 10.2.0
V8: 6.6.346.32
OS: Windows_NT x64 10.0.18362

I also double checked that the problem is on the Insider's Build.

**Steps to Reproduce:**

1. Observe text on screen. It should have gray subpixel rendering.
![1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14015672/59582781-56b2b000-90a7-11e9-9883-77a1524f9e91.png)
2. Open menu bar.
3. Observe text on screen. It should have RGB subpixel rendering.
![2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14015672/59582788-5c0ffa80-90a7-11e9-9a32-7ece84eda963.png)

This issue occurs on all text (except the menu bar submenus). I noticed it, because the text rendering looks better, but only when the menu bar was open! I would prefer all of it to use RGB subpixel rendering, like my other applications.

**Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?:** Yes

title: Option to set the size of the undo/redo history
body:
- VSCode Version: 1.35.1
- OS Version: OSX 10.14.5

Steps to Reproduce:

- Make many changes in a file (I'd say at least 30)
- Try to undo them.

Duplicate of [this issue](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/10396), which has not been resolved. Undo history is not unlimited as it is suggested.

Would be nice to have an option in the settings to configure the number of undo/redo.

title: launch.json: "${command:pickProcess}" prompts for a process to attach to *before* running pre-launch tasks
body:
As of VSCode v1.35.1, a launch configuration defined in `launch.json` that uses `"${command:pickProcess}"` as its `"processId"` value - in order to prompt for a process to attach to - does so *before* running any pre-launch tasks (`preLaunchTask` property).

* Is this by design?
* Is there a way to reverse this order?

The reason I want my prelaunch task to run _first_ is twofold:

* generally, since my prelaunch task includes building, I want the launch to be aborted if building fails.

* specifically, my prelaunch task _creates_  the process that I then want to attach to.

Taking a step back, my ideal solution would be to have the prelaunch task not only _create_ the process to attach to, but to have the launch configuration _automatically attach_ to it afterwards, but I haven't found a way to do that, given that:

*  starting the debugger from the command line isn't supported yet - though support is being considered - see #10979

* there seems to be no way to populate a launch-configuration property from an arbitrary shell command (you can only call VSCode-internal commands via `${command:...}`).

Note: I hit this limitation when trying to debug binary PowerShell modules via an external PowerShell console. I've since realized that the C# debugger _automatically_ attaches to any external process created via a `"request": "launch"` launch configuration, so launching a PowerShell console that way (with a startup command that imports the binary module) is sufficient.

title: Better documentation for individual settings
Snippet Choice confirm choice should move to next placeholder
body: When I confirm choice on a Snippet Choice options, it just stay at current placeholder and need to hit `Tab` to move to next placeholder. For a better developer experience, I think it should move to the next placeholder automatically. It because I already confirmed the choice, there is no reason stay at current placeholder.
